t: Job 39
“Do*pn you know when the mountain goats give birth? Do*ld you watch when the doe bears her fawn?
Do*ln you count the months till they bear? Do*ld you know the time they give birth?
They*ln crouch down and bring forth their young; their*ld labor pains are ended.
Their*ln young thrive and grow strong in the wilds; they*ld leave and do not return.
“Who*pn let the wild donkey go free? Who*ld untied its ropes?
I*ln gave it the wasteland as its home, the*ld salt flats as its habitat.
It*ln laughs at the commotion in the town; it*ld does not hear a driver’s shout.
It*ln ranges the hills for its pasture and*ld searches for any green thing.
“Will*pn the wild ox consent to serve you? Will*ld it stay by your manger at night?
Can*ln you hold it to the furrow with a harness? Will*ld it till the valleys behind you?
Will*ln you rely on it for its great strength? Will*ld you leave your heavy work to it?
Can*ln you trust it to haul in your grain and*ld bring it to your threshing floor?
“The*pn wings of the ostrich flap joyfully, though*ld they cannot compare with*ld the wings and feathers of the stork.
She*ln lays her eggs on the ground and*ld lets them warm in the sand,
unmindful*ln that a foot may crush them, that*ld some wild animal may trample them.
She*ln treats her young harshly, as if they were not hers; she*ld cares not that her labor was in vain,
for*ln God did not endow her with wisdom or*ld give her a share of good sense.
Yet*ln when she spreads her feathers to run, she*ld laughs at horse and rider.
“Do*pn you give the horse its strength or*ld clothe its neck with a flowing mane?
Do*ln you make it leap like a locust, striking*ld terror with its proud snorting?
It*ln paws fiercely, rejoicing in its strength, and*ld charges into the fray.
It*ln laughs at fear, afraid of nothing; it*ld does not shy away from the sword.
The*ln quiver rattles against its side, along*ld with the flashing spear and lance.
In*ln frenzied excitement it eats up the ground; it*ld cannot stand still when the trumpet sounds.
At*ln the blast of the trumpet it snorts, ‘Aha!’ It*ld catches the scent of battle from afar, the*ld shout of commanders and the battle cry.
“Does*pn the hawk take flight by your wisdom and*ld spread its wings toward the south?
Does*ln the eagle soar at your command and*ld build its nest on high?
It*ln dwells on a cliff and stays there at night; a*ld rocky crag is its stronghold.
From*ln there it looks for food; its*ld eyes detect it from afar.
Its*ln young ones feast on blood, and*ld where the slain are, there it is.”
